questions.text: A 65-year old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure increases with age due to decreased arterial wall compliance.

With advancing age, there is an increase in systolic blood pressure. Whilst diastolic blood pressure falls after 60 years of age due to increased arterial stiffness (decreased compliance). As a result of these two changes, pulse pressure increases (↑PP = ↑SBP - ↓DBP).

questions.text: Which of the following curves represents gamma-globin chain production?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the Orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production. Gamma globin chain is produced in the fetal period and drops to undetectable levels 6 months postpartum which is the pattern represented by the Orange curve.

Hemoglobin in blood has different variants throughout life, in different proportions. The type of hemoglobin essentially depends on the combination of globin chains. Adult hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. Other combinations of chains can be found in embryonic hemoglobin.

Here,

  • Gamma chain - Orange curve
  • Alpha chain - Red curve
  • Beta chain - Green curve
  • Epsilon chain - Black curve
  • Delta chain - Blue curve

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?
questions.solution:
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of pain pathway in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibers are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance?

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.solution:
The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

The parameters used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) are:

  • Urine creatinine
  • Serum creatinine
  • 24hr urine output

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

        UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine(mg/dl)

PCr - Serum creatinine(mg/dl)

V - Urine volume(ml/24 hrs)

Creatinine is a metabolite of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body mostly by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

Urine collection for the measurement of creatinine clearance may be subject to practical constraints. Therefore, approximate changes in GFR can be obtained by measuring the serum creatinine concentration, which is inversely proportional to GFR.

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
A single neuron receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons is an example of convergence.

Convergence means signals from multiple inputs uniting to excite a single neuron. It can be of 2 types:

  • Convergence from a single source
  • Convergence from multiple sources

The importance of convergence is that neurons are almost never excited by an action potential from a single input terminal. However, action potentials converging on the neuron from multiple terminals provide enough spatial summation to bring the neuron to the threshold required for discharge.

questions.text: Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml.
questions.solution:
ECF volume of the above volunteer is calculated to be 14 L.

The ECF volume can be calculated using the formula:

Where,
  • V = ECF volume
  • Amount injected = 10 gm
  • Amount of mannitol excreted = 10% of 10 gm = 1gm
  • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100mL = 0.65 gm/L 

Calculation:

 ECF Volume = (10-1)/0.65

                   = 13.8 L = approximately 14 L

Mannitol cannot cross cell membranes, hence, it will be distributed in ECF but not in ICF. Thus mannitol is a marker for ECF volume and therefore calculating the volume of distribution of mannitol gives the value of ECF volume.

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to?
questions.solution:
Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

Donnan and Gibbs showed that "When an ion on one side of a membrane cannot diffuse through the membrane, the distribution of other ions to which the membrane is permeable is affected in a predictable way".

According to this, in the presence of intracellular proteins, which are negatively charged non-diffusable ions, the distribution of other ions to which the membrane is permeable is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by?
questions.solution:
Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

In the last decade, a class of small, heterogeneous, secreted vesicles, broadly termed as extracellular vesicles have been identified.

These extracellular vesicles have been implicated as a new and important mediator of cell-cell communication that likely contributes importantly to both normal and pathologic physiology.

These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer.

They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 nm diameter), and are generated by at least two distinct mechanisms:

  • Microvesicles are generated by budding from the plasma membrane of a source cell.
  • Exosomes are generated from the multivesicular body (MVB).

Note: The terms microvesicle and exosome are often lumped together as simply exosomes.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors show mechanical coupling involving structural interaction between the two.

Dihydropyridine receptors (DHPRs) are voltage-gated Ca2+ channels in the T tubule membrane. 

The ryanodine receptor (RyR) is a ligand-gated Ca2+ channel with Ca2+ as its natural ligand.

Skeletal muscle excitation-contraction (E-C) coupling is thought to occur by a "mechanical coupling" mechanism involving protein-protein interactions that lead to activation of the sarcoplasmic reticulum ryanodine receptor by the voltage-sensing transverse (T-) tubule dihydropyridine receptor.

questions.text: In negative feedback, feedback gain of infinity is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
In negative feedback, feedback gain of infinity could be seen in blood volume control by the kidney.

When the blood volume falls below the equilibrium, the renal–body fluid mechanism causes the blood volume returns back to the equilibrium point resulting in zero error and hence the gain of kidney in its ability to regulate blood volume is infinity (∞).

The degree of effectiveness with which a regulatory system maintains constant conditions is determined by the gain of the negative feedback system. 

Gain= Correction/Error

Example: If an external or internal factor led to a decrease in mean blood pressure from 100 mm Hg to 80 mm Hg. Activation of a negative feedback mechanism i.e. baroreflex leads to a correction of blood pressure to 96 mm Hg. So in this case,

  • Correction = 16 mm Hg
  • Error = 4 mm Hg
  • Gain = Correction/Error = 16/4 = 4

Note: A gain of 0 would imply a total failure of the regulatory system and a gain of infinity (∞) would indicate complete restoration of the regulated variable.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100Hz tuning fork).
questions.solution:
The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period. It is the frequency at which individual muscle fibres twitch that fuse and cause sustained muscle contraction, where the contraction period is the time taken from latent period to maximum force of contraction.

In this case, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means the tracer recorded 100 waves per second.
Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.

In the image given in the question, between the point B (end of latent period) to point C (maximum force of contraction), there are about 5 waves.
Hence, the duration of contraction = 5 x 0.01 = 0.05 seconds.

Substituting the value in the formula, we get:
Tetanizing frequency = 1/0.05 sec = 100/5 = 20/sec.

Tetanization:

The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. Beyond this point, a further increase in the frequency, will not result in increased force of contraction.

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

The Basal electrical rhythm (BER) also called slow-wave, is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. It is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV.

The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:

  • Stomach: 4/min
  • Duodenum: 12/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension.

Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension. Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

Muscle contraction can occur only when the motor stimulus is provided during the depolarisation part of the BER.

Thus, BER does not cause muscle contraction by itself, but controls the rate and organization sites of the muscle contractions, as in coordination of the peristaltic activity and setting the rhythm of segmentation.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule.

The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts:

  • Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT,  the concentration of all of the following decreases except:
questions.solution:
As the filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule, the concentration of the chloride increases.

  • The concentration of chloride in the early part of the pCT is ≈105 mEq/L.
  • As the sodium is reabsorbed, it preferentially carries glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate.
  • This leaves behind the solute, that has a higher concentration of the chloride, which as it reaches the second half of the PCT is ≈140 mEq/L.

questions.text: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C respectively.
questions.solution:
In the given graph, the order of filterability is A>B>C, which likely indicates that the substances are Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic.

The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative charged (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered.

Hence, the order of filterability would be: Polycationic > Neutral > Polyanionic, represented by A, B, and C in the graph shown.

The glomerular filtration barrier consists of:

  • Endothelium of the capillary
  • Basement membrane: 
    • Lamina densa - electron-dense layer. It contains type IV collagen
    • Lamina rara interna - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge
    • Lamina rara externa - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge
  • Layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane

The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches zero.

However, in addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The property can be studied by using charged dextran.

When the filtration of the negatively and positively charged dextrans was studied, the results indicated that the negatively charged dextrans in the blood are repelled, with the result that filtration of anionic substances 4 nm in diameter is less than half that of neutral substances of the same size.

This explains, why albumin despite having an effective molecular diameter of approximately 7 nm, has a very low filtration rate.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled is 200ml/min and O2 consumed is 250 ml/min.
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient is 0.8.

The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization.

In the given question, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the O2 consumption is 250mL/min.

Therefore,

Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.

  • When carbohydrates are metabolized with one molecule of oxygen, one carbon dioxide molecule is released. Therefore, the RQ of carbohydrates = 1.
  • When fats are oxidized, for every 100 molecules of oxygen consumed, 70 molecules of CO2 are released. Therefore, the RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • Similarly, the respiratory quotient for proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: Which of the following types of amino acids are present in the transmembranous part of the membrane receptor?
questions.solution:
The transmembranous part of the membrane receptor consists of hydrophobic amino acids.

A membrane protein can be either integral protein (spans the thickness of the cell membrane) or peripheral protein (attached to the peripheral side of the membrane). The membrane-spanning segment of integral proteins are usually hydrophobic alpha-helices.

The central core of the cell membrane is hydrophobic. Integral proteins have their hydrophobic portions usually in the interior of the membrane and the hydrophilic portions towards the surfaces. The presence of these hydrophobic amino acids in the interior is a special adaptation that allows the protein to remain stable in the hydrophobic milieu of the cell membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland, which causes primary hyperparathyroidism (not secondary).

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by high levels of parathyroid hormone, to compensate for the low levels of serum calcium, due to some other underlying condition.

Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism, include:

  • Chronic kidney disease: The damaged kidneys are unable to produce sufficient amounts of the active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. This further causes hypocalcemia and triggers PTH secretion.
  • Vitamin D deficiency: Causes hypocalcemia, which triggers the increased secretion of PTH.
  • Lithium: May cause an increased set-point of calcium for parathyroid hormone suppression, which leads to parathyroid hyperplasia.

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing?

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.solution:
There is a decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

  • When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output.
  • Reduced cardiac output, leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing from baroreceptors.
  • As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed leading to increased heart rate.

 

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction?
  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarisation.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

Steps in relaxation:

  • The cytoplasmic calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, by the action of SERCA (sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase).
  • Once the calcium concentration is lowered, the interaction between actin and myosin ceases, and the muscle relaxes. 
 
Other options:
 
Statement 1: Incorrect - Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction. When there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.
 
Statement 2: Incorrect - Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. It is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
 
Statement 4: Voltage-gated calcium channels on T-tubules (part of sarcolemma) are activated by a depolarizing stimulus, which causes the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The increased calcium concentration will eventually lead to muscle contraction.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarisation, repolarisation, and hyperpolarisation in a skeletal muscle action potential?
  1. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarisation due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct.

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes end-plate potential, which when reaches to a threshold value, causes action potential in the muscle fibre.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre is caused by the activation of the voltage-gated sodium channels, which causes the influx of sodium.
  • During repolarization, the sodium channels are closed, and voltage-gated potassium channels open, which causes efflux of potassium.
  • The voltage-gated potassium channels close slowly. As a result, the potassium efflux continues, leading to hyperpolarization of the membrane.

The steps in an action potential in muscle fibre and the neuron, are similar except for the quantitative differences, such as:

  • RMP is -80 to -90 mV in skeletal muscle fibres, while it is about -70mV in neurons.
  • The duration of the action potential in skeletal muscle is 1 to 5 msec, which is about 5 times longer than in the largest myelinated nerve fibre.
  • The velocity of conduction is about 3-5m/s, which is about 1/13th of the velocity of the nerve fibre.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events in the sequence in which they occur, after 'p wave' in ECG:
  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, ie:-

a wave in JVP → First heart sound  → T wave in ECG  → Rapid filling of ventricles.

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

  • The p wave in the ECG represents atrial depolarization, which causes contraction of the atria, represented by the 'a' wave in the JVP. Atrial contraction causes final filling of the ventricles (fourth phase of ventricular diastole) 
  • Atrial contraction is followed by the closure of the mitral valve, which causes the first-heart sound.
  • This is followed by the isovolumetric contraction of the ventricle, which causes c wave in JVP, due to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This is followed by the rapid ejection phase of the ventricle.
  • The T wave of ECG occurs during ventricular repolarization, which is followed by the opening of the mitral valve, followed by rapid filling phase of the ventricle (second  phase of ventricular diastole).

Note: Passive rapid filling occurs as the mitral valve opens just before atrial contraction occurs.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased.
     

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.
